Boil order lifted, water safe to drink

The Leicester Water Supply District and Hillcrest Water District notified customers that the “boil order” had been lifted and tap water was once again safe to use without extraordinary measures.

A notice to customers said the problem with the Pierce Spring town well, from which the E. coli sample had been found earlier in the week, had been identified and corrected.

The nature of the problem was not disclosed but the lifting of the boil order was approved by the state Department of Environmental Protection.

Both districts will continue to add chlorine to the water supply.

Those with questions should contact Roger Hammond at (508) 892-8484, or (508) 892-7525.

Water main connection will cause boil advisory
This poll is not scientific and is meant for entertainment purposes.
logEmailArticle(); // evt.data.service is specific to the ""addthis.menu.share"" event

RAVEN RUN - Water customers served in most areas by the Municipal Authority of the Borough of Shenandoah will be under a boil advisory this week because of work being done on the distribution system.

The work scheduled for Monday will be the connection of a new 12-inch water main about 600 feet long located on Locust Mountain between the water filtration plant near Raven Run and the Glover's Hill section of Shenandoah.

MABS customers living in Shenandoah, Shenandoah Heights, Weston Place, Turkey Run and Brownsville will be under a boil water advisory starting Monday and will continue until further notice. Water must be boiled for consumption purposes. Customers may also experience low pressure, dirty water and possibly no water at times.

According to MABS foreman Rich Mensick, the pipe had been placed and is ready for the connection.

""We're doing the work to connect a distribution main to the borough,"" said Mensick. ""The line is all laid, so all we have to do is tie the mains together. The work won't take long to do the connection, but until we do sanitation and get everything in order, it's going to take a while.""

Mensick said the move of the water main was prompted by a request from Girard Estate in order to mine coal. The cost of the pipe, excavation, installation and other expenses have been paid by the company and not the authority. The municipal authority monitored the installation to assure that everything is in compliance with Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection regulations.

Other areas served by the authority, such as the villages of William Penn and Lost Creek, are not affected since they receive water through a different water main.

Mensick said the boil advisory will remain in effect until testing is completed.

""It's going to be at least several days,"" he said.

Boil water order issued for Mountain Empire High School
PINE VALLEY (CNS) - A boil water order was issued Friday for Mountain Empire High School after total coliform bacteria was discovered in its drinking water system, county officials announced.

The order for the school at 3305 Buckman Springs Road in Pine Valley will remain in effect until the system has been disinfected and additional samples confirm there is no more bacteria in the water, according to the San Diego County Department of Environmental Health.
Total coliform bacteria can come from soils and other sources in the environment, the county advised.

E. coli found in Leicester well

column5: Because of the water problem, school at Leicester Middle School was dismissed early. However, this morning students and parents took part in a festive graduation ceremony.

column1: Residents drawing water from Leicester and Hillcrest Water districts have been instructed to boil tap water before drinking it, and to take additional precautions. Water district officials learned Wednesday night that a sample taken the day before from the Pierce Spring Well tested positive for E. coli, an indicator of fecal bacteria.

column5: By Bradford L. Miner TELEGRAM & GAZETTE STAFF

column1:
Residents drawing water from Leicester and Hillcrest Water districts have been instructed to boil tap water before drinking it, and to take additional precautions.

Water district officials learned Wednesday night that a sample taken the day before from the Pierce Spring Well tested positive for E. coli, an indicator of fecal bacteria.

Additional precautions include all discarding all ice, beverages, uncooked foods, and formula made with tap water collected on or before Tuesday.


The water district immediately removed the well from service, drawing from the remaining five wells on the system. According to district officials, because the Hillcrest district routinely buys water from Leicester, its users were notified of the boil order as well.

To reduce risk of exposure to either bacterial or viral contamination, water district officials are recommending that all water intended for drinking, cooking, making ice, preparing food, washing dishes and brushing teeth should be boiled for a minimum of one minute.

Only fully-prepared infant formula that does not require mixing should be used until the potential danger has passed, officials said

The alternative is to use bottled water in those specific instances.

District officials said they are monitoring the situation, awaiting the results of further testing to determine when the risk of contamination has been resolved.

Until such time, the Pierce Spring Well will remain off line as district employees look for signs of contamination, disinfect the water with chlorine and flush hydrants.

To make certain there is residual chorine throughout the water system, there may be a slight odor and discoloration detectable.

Users will be advised when boil precautions are no longer necessary.

Additional information is available at the Leicester Water District website, the Hillcrest Water District website and the town of Leicester website.
